WRITING.TEXT: April fools. Trololol. TOFU by not remembering the date.
There are some horrifying videos on YouTube about the effects of it.
Go back to high school 507 was phenomenal

I would base this decision on your stats experience. 221 is hell for everyone- even if you told calc in high school. Stats is pretty easy, honestly. But that's only if you have some stats background. Some of my classmates didn't take AP stats and struggled with it.

Oh man, I feel you big time in this. I did IP and PHP and while that was necessary for medical stabilization, the way it really helped me was ERP type shit. Forcing me to be scared and deal with it. But at the same time, it was isolating because most of the people around me had the pro ana thin stuff going on. But my problem was absolutely paralyzingly fear stemming from OCD and an inability to make a decision. I'm super lucky in that my outpatient therapist specializes in both anorexia and OCD.
That's a huge victory!!! Way to go; you should be damn proud.

I eat something that scares me. Seriously. It sounds horrible and counterintuitive but it really helps. If you look into DBT skills, it's the one about doing the opposite of what you want to do in the moment.
No problem, and good luck to you!

I worked in a lab my junior year but other than that, I have like nothing haha. I had to apply a few times though; mayo likes persistence so don't be discouraged if you apply several times for different positions and are rejected. Their application system is weird.

Not OP, but this post really really really hit home for me. I'm nowhere near as far into recovery, but the Ed has cost me similar things and had similar negative impacts and the way you worded it an everything was just perfection. Thank you. I mean that.

I'm a pharmacy pathology research assistant (so like antibiotics and such). It's amazing. Mayo is so legit to work for and if you are remotely interested in this kind of thing, I highly recommend you apply. The insurance is amazing, it pays well for a starting job, and they help out with your advanced education fees after you are employed for a year. Rochester may not be the most exciting place in the world, but the bar scene is full of interesting young medical field workers.

I'm going to bring it up again with my therapist the next time I see her. I was never physically or sexually abused, but there's been some verbal in there with my dad (diagnosed narcissist) so depending on how that shit primes one's brain for PTSD from anorexia, it's possible. Obviously, the plural of anecdote is not data, but what you said about your friend is really interestingly relevant. Hmm.
Glad I'm not alone. My therapist and I are working on this now. Grounding exercises and such.

I for sure think there's some aspect of this. When I was in the hospital, I couldn't remember any of this stuff. It was all I could do to get through the days and to keep going but now it's coming flooding back as I'm better nourished.

2015 graduate. I entered treatment for anorexia after graduating which set my life timeline back a bit, but I am happy to announce that I am finally working at Mayo using my microbiology degree. Considering taking some classes to go back for a PhD or something in a few years.

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone else in recovery have scary flashbacks to the depths of their Ed?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm doing so so so much better than I was even a few months ago. And, while I still have work to do, I'm really proud of myself. That being said, I keep having horrible flashbacks to the sadness, emptiness, and physical pain of my Ed. I took my ability to tolerate that as a sign that I was a strong person back when I was in the depths, but just how damn close I was to dying of anorexia is really starting to sink in. The painful cold randomly comes to mind as well as the anxiety ridden doctors appointments where they told me about my heart issues and I panicked about potentially having to go IP. And the guilt I felt when sitting and running despite the risk to my heart. It all makes me sick and terrified to think about. My best friend was scared of/ for me and stopped returning my texts.
I finally have a full time job and social life. I eat and exercise almost normally so I'm not sure why all these memories decided to start flooding back now. I think I just needed to emote; sorry for the rant.

Yes, I was going to say this.
Some days I'm still fighting to walk towards the light.

Same here. Not quite as long of a commute but I have to drive, park, and bus in to the city so probably 80mins round trip.
I have found the pre work workout to be a godsend. I get it over with in the morning and feel energized and accomplish start my day. The exercise makes it easier for me to focus on my work coupled with a nice cup of coffee.
For food, the meal prep is for sure key. I like one pot things- chili and such. I can freeze it for dinners when I'm too tired to cook or bring to work for lunch. I work in a hospital, so I'm lucky in that if I forget a lunch, the staff cafeteria has really healthy options but I try to prep up chicken breasts and grab a bag of salad.
For sure!
There's a really really good Ted talk on this.
I think there is still a kik group active? But you're welcome to PM me if you want to talk!

I have an issue with utensils and bowls and such too! I like plastic. I only eat with plastic spoons. I much prefer bowls to plates. My favorite spoon is a tiny 1/8th teaspoon one- or using a knife to eat like yogurt. Dip it and lick it. And dip it again.
UVA needs the Heimlich maneuver for that choke. That was incredible on Syracuse's part. Holy.Fucking.Shit.
Holy fucking shit.
Major rebound there.
I know,right? Went to the bathroom. Came back to a completely different game.
Holy hell, that fake was beautiful.

Don't make fun of things people can't control: pretty much any physical feature, the way they talk, the way the walk etc. I had some "friends" early in college who would constantly put me down and mock my personality and would say they were "just joking" and that if I didn't find it funny, it was because I was "too sensitive" and lacked their "wit". Fuck those guys.

My anorexia diagnosis. My mindset has forever been changed and my life will never be the same. I had to move back in with my mom and put more than I have ever thought into recovering. And I will forever be in recovery- relapse is something I'm going to have to watch myself for every time anything remotely stressful goes down in my life.

It is definitely not your fault. I'm sorry your OCD thoughts are beating you up so much. :(. I know there's no one cure all, but DBT skills have been so helpful for me. I have a lot of issues with intrusive thoughts and have found DBT helpful for this with the focus on redirecting your thoughts, mindfulness, and erp with some of the nasty thoughts. It was created for BPD, but don't let that fool you.
Oven roasted and covered in garlic salt is heaven for pretty much any veggie. Yummmm.

Honestly, I'm not even disappointed. With the way this season started, I was so anxious about where we would end up come tournament time. We went above and beyond what I thought possible this year. Great season boys; next year will be even better.
As a microbio graduate, I am loving this season even more.

Just wanted to let you know that you aren't alone. I feel like such an infant because of how sensitive I am right now to comments and stuff. I am told that it gets better with time; you get desensitized to it.

I mean, the fact that someone is able to commit suicide in a secure psychiatric facility is pretty abhorrent. It's the third one in Minnesota in the past year after 30 years of none. That's crazy.
Also, he spent 90 days in a normal hospital before waiting for placement. Why didn't social services step in to help him with his case?

My friend was a close friend of his brother, and my mom was one of the attending doctors for part of his extensive hospital stay effort he was transferred to the St. Peter facility. The American social work and mental health system really failed this poor guy. There ought to be a serious investigation into all of the circumstances leading up to his suicide.
Same issue here! I'm working on cBT and DBT skills with my therapist which seem to be helping. Especially the DBT even though I'm not remotely borderline, it's pretty useful for anorexia.
U RAH RAH
Oh god yeah. "How did you get your legs like that?!" I literally starve myself and exercise compulsively. They really compliment my failing heart, don't they? Ugh.

I've had this happen to. People just aren't used to looking for underweight j think. Like it's easy to spot obesity, but we assume thinner is better. Fuck, I got compliments on how great my legs looked at bmi 17.1. It's definitely hard to hear honestly because the Ed part of my brain would immediately jump to "oh you look fine like this. People finally are complimenting you on your physical appearance." It's a tough spot to be in.

I never did IOP, but I did PHP which is fairly similar. I found it really helpful to have support for the meals. It helped me to get over some fear foods and restore some weight. They had a meal plan all set up so I didn't have a chance to make myself crazy fearing that I overate or whatever. And there were days off in between as I got further along which were great practice.

The you never had an Ed thoughts the worst. It's such a mindfuck and makes you think you were crazy and just making stuff up. And for me, it's usually followed by "well if you have an Ed, prove it. Restrict". Which sends me on a downward spiral if I'm not careful.
The Nutella commercials always anger me. A healthy breakfast spread? Come on. I love Nutella but let's be real- it's frosting.

Thank you so much for posting this. My anorexia and compulsive exercise developed off a healthy love of distance running, and I'm glad that awareness is being spread.
To anyone reading this who thinks they are developing a problem with food or exercise, please reach out and get help. The sooner the better. Recovering is hard but so so worth it.
That could be water then too if it happened so quick. But I totally get how anxiety provoking it is. :/

Yup, yup. Your body puts fat around the abdomen first after a period of starvation to protect your organs. This will eventually redistribute itself after a prolonged period of sustained nutrition.
Congrats on the recovery! It's hard work.
My name's Blurryface and I care what you think.
Cocaine.

As someone recovering from anorexia, I can confirm. It's only as my bmi has gotten into the low 20's that I've had more energy. Granted OP probably doesn't have an eating disorder based on the information in this post, eating more would help him. For reference, I'm an inch shorter and female and my doctors want me to restore to about 150.
Hahaha, I know doctors can do them but money. Maybe there's a way to buy them cheaply online?

Really interesting theory about the progesterone refractory period type thing. Based on my understanding, you're along the right lines. In basic terms, estrogen is a stimulating hormone to the brain while progesterone is calming. Too much estrogen and too little progesterone, and you are irritable and have trouble sleeping. So maybe the progesterone is too high before and then it drops before the estrogen is being regulated to drop and that's why your extremes are so variable? You could try doing saliva hormone tests on certain days and compare them. For science.
I think you have the wrong thread.

My understanding is that you are at the peak of your hormones before they drop. And that causes it. Happens to me too. I can't sleep much, but I don't even need it. I can do all the things on half the sleep. Supposedly, your body is better at burning fat during this time as in it uses it more preferentially than during other times of the month.

Oh man, same deal for me. I'm getting better now, but I had the same need to run a certain amounts and then would walk constantly. Or at a very minimum stand. I walked everywhere- even places the bus was faster and when the weather was cold. I did homework standing up and browsed the Internet on my iPad wandering around the house. Sometimes, I would "forget" things places to give me an excuse for more movement, to hide the compulsiveness. You're certainly not alone; I understand how physically and mentally exhausting it is.
